title: Weighted Average Cost of Capital
notes: This equation calculates the weighted average cost of capital. WACC represents the blended cost of financing, w_e and w_d are the weights of equity and debt, r_e and r_d are the costs of equity and debt, and T is the corporate tax rate. WACC is used as the discount rate for DCF valuation and is a key input in capital budgeting decisions. The cost of capital represents the required return that investors demand.

title: Cost of Equity (CAPM)
notes: This equation calculates the cost of equity using the Capital Asset Pricing Model. r_e represents the expected return on equity, r_f is the risk-free rate, beta measures systematic risk, and (r_m - r_f) is the market risk premium. CAPM is the most widely used method for estimating the cost of equity. The cost of capital represents the required return that investors demand.

title: Cost of Equity (Dividend Growth)
notes: This equation calculates the cost of equity using the constant growth dividend model. r_e represents the cost of equity, D_1 is the expected dividend, P_0 is the current stock price, and g is the constant dividend growth rate. This method is appropriate for stable dividend-paying companies. The cost of capital represents the required return that investors demand.

title: Cost of Debt
notes: This equation calculates the after-tax cost of debt. r_d represents the after-tax cost of debt, YTM is the yield to maturity on the company's debt, and T is the corporate tax rate. Interest is tax-deductible, so the after-tax cost is lower than the pre-tax yield. The cost of capital represents the required return that investors demand.

title: Cost of Preferred Stock
notes: This equation calculates the cost of preferred stock. r_p represents the cost of preferred stock, D_p is the annual dividend, and P_p is the current price of preferred stock. Preferred dividends are not tax-deductible, so no tax adjustment is needed. The cost of capital represents the required return that investors demand.

title: Unlevered Cost of Equity
notes: This equation calculates the unlevered cost of equity using the Hamada equation. r_u represents the unlevered cost of equity, r_e is the levered cost of equity, r_d is the cost of debt, r_f is the risk-free rate, D/E is the debt-to-equity ratio, and T is the tax rate. This formula adjusts for financial leverage. The cost of capital represents the required return that investors demand.

title: Levered Beta
notes: This equation calculates the levered beta from the unlevered beta. beta_L represents the levered beta (accounting for financial leverage), beta_U is the unlevered beta (asset beta), D/E is the debt-to-equity ratio, and T is the corporate tax rate. Higher leverage increases systematic risk. The cost of capital represents the required return that investors demand.

title: Unlevered Beta
notes: This equation calculates the unlevered beta from the levered beta. beta_U represents the asset beta (business risk only), beta_L is the levered beta, D/E is the debt-to-equity ratio, and T is the corporate tax rate. Unlevered beta is used to compare companies with different capital structures. The cost of capital represents the required return that investors demand.

title: Market Risk Premium
notes: This equation calculates the market risk premium. MRP represents the excess return of the market over the risk-free rate, E[R_m] is the expected market return, and r_f is the risk-free rate. MRP reflects the compensation investors require for bearing systematic market risk.

title: Adjusted Present Value
notes: This equation calculates the adjusted present value of a firm. APV represents the firm value, V_u is the unlevered firm value, PV(tax shield) is the present value of interest tax shields, and PV(costs) is the present value of financial distress costs. APV is useful for LBO and project valuation.

title: Enterprise Value
equation_latex: EV = Market \text{Cap} + Total Debt - Cash + Minority Interest + Preferred Stock
notes: This equation calculates the enterprise value. EV represents the total value of a company available to all investors, Market Cap is equity value, Total Debt includes interest-bearing debt, Cash is subtracted (reduces value), and minority interest and preferred stock are added. EV is used in valuation multiples.

title: Terminal Value (Gordon Growth)
notes: This equation calculates terminal value using the Gordon growth model. TV represents the present value of all future free cash flows beyond the projection period, FCF_{n+1} is the first year post-projection free cash flow, WACC is the discount rate, and g is the perpetual growth rate. Terminal value often accounts for 60-80% of total firm value.

title: Terminal Value (Exit Multiple)
notes: This equation calculates terminal value using an exit multiple. TV represents the terminal value, EBITDA_{exit} is the projected EBITDA at the exit date, and EV_Multiple is the industry benchmark multiple. This method is widely used in private equity and investment banking.

title: Free Cash Flow to Firm
notes: This equation calculates free cash flow to the firm. FCFF represents the cash available to all investors after reinvestment, EBIT is earnings before interest and taxes, T is the tax rate, D&A is depreciation and amortization, CapEx is capital expenditure, and Change in NWC is the change in net working capital.

title: Free Cash Flow to Equity
equation_latex: \text{FCFE} = Net Income + \text{D&A} - \text{CapEx} + Net Borrowing - Change in NWC
notes: This equation calculates free cash flow to equity. FCFE represents the cash available to equity holders after all expenses, debt payments, and reinvestments. Net Income is the starting point, D&A is added back, CapEx and working capital changes are subtracted, and net borrowing is added.

title: Earnings Before Interest and Taxes
notes: This equation calculates earnings before interest and taxes. EBIT represents the operating profit of the company, Revenue is total sales, COGS is cost of goods sold, and Operating Expenses include SG&A, R&D, and other operating costs. EBIT is used in valuation multiples and DCF analysis.

title: Net Operating Profit After Tax
notes: This equation calculates net operating profit after tax. NOPAT represents the operating profit available to all investors after taxes, EBIT is operating profit, and T is the tax rate. NOPAT is used in EVA calculations and measures the true operating performance.

title: Economic Value Added
notes: This equation calculates Economic Value Added. EVA represents the value created by the company above its cost of capital, NOPAT is net operating profit after tax, WACC is the weighted average cost of capital, and Capital is the invested capital. Positive EVA indicates value creation.

title: Return on Invested Capital
notes: This equation calculates return on invested capital. ROIC represents the return on all capital invested in the business, NOPAT is net operating profit after tax, and Invested Capital is total debt plus equity minus cash. ROIC measures how efficiently the company uses its capital.

title: Price to Earnings Ratio
equation_latex: P/E = Price per Share / Earnings per Share
notes: This equation calculates the price-to-earnings ratio. P/E represents how much investors pay per dollar of earnings, Price per Share is the stock price, and Earnings per Share is net income divided by shares outstanding. P/E is the most common valuation multiple.

title: Enterprise Value to EBITDA
notes: This equation calculates the EV to EBITDA multiple. EV/EBITDA represents the enterprise value relative to operating cash generation, Enterprise Value is total firm value, and EBITDA is earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization. This multiple is useful for comparing companies with different capital structures.

title: Price to Book Ratio
equation_latex: P/B = Price per Share / Book Value per Share
notes: This equation calculates the price-to-book ratio. P/B represents how much investors pay per dollar of book value, Price per Share is the stock price, and Book Value per Share is total equity divided by shares outstanding. P/B is particularly relevant for financial institutions.

title: Price to Sales Ratio
notes: This equation calculates the price-to-sales ratio. P/S represents the market capitalization relative to annual revenue, Market Cap is equity value, and Total Revenue is annual sales. P/S is useful for unprofitable companies and early-stage businesses.

title: EV to Sales Ratio
notes: This equation calculates the enterprise value to sales ratio. EV/Sales represents the total firm value relative to annual revenue, which is useful for comparing companies with different capital structures and profitability levels.

title: Sustainable Growth Rate
notes: This equation calculates the sustainable growth rate. g represents the maximum growth rate a company can achieve without additional financing, ROE is return on equity, and Retention Ratio is the proportion of earnings retained (1 - dividend payout ratio).

title: Return on Equity
notes: This equation calculates return on equity. ROE represents how much profit the company generates per dollar of equity investment, Net Income is after all expenses and taxes, and Shareholders' Equity is total assets minus total liabilities. ROE is a key measure of profitability.

title: Return on Assets
notes: This equation calculates return on assets. ROA represents how much profit the company generates per dollar of assets, Net Income is after all expenses, and Total Assets is the sum of current and non-current assets. ROA measures overall asset efficiency.

title: Dividend Payout Ratio
equation_latex: \text{DPR} = Dividends per Share / Earnings per Share
notes: This equation calculates the dividend payout ratio. DPR represents the percentage of earnings paid as dividends, Dividends per Share is the annual dividend, and Earnings per Share is net income per share. A higher payout ratio means less earnings are retained for reinvestment.

title: Retention Ratio
notes: This equation calculates the retention ratio. Retention Ratio represents the proportion of earnings retained in the business rather than paid as dividends. Higher retention ratios indicate the company is reinvesting more earnings for future growth.

title: Gordon Growth Model
notes: This equation calculates the intrinsic value of a stock using the constant growth dividend model. P_0 represents the current stock price, D_1 is the expected dividend next period, r is the required return on equity, and g is the constant dividend growth rate. This model assumes perpetual constant growth.

title: Two-Stage Dividend Discount Model
notes: This equation calculates the intrinsic value using a two-stage dividend model. P_0 represents the stock price, D_t are dividends in the high-growth stage, r is the discount rate, and P_n is the terminal price calculated using Gordon growth at the end of year n.

title: Discounted Cash Flow Valuation
notes: This equation calculates the enterprise value using DCF analysis. V_0 represents the current firm value, FCF_t are projected free cash flows, WACC is the discount rate, and TV is the terminal value. DCF is the fundamental valuation methodology in finance.

title: Internal Rate of Return
notes: This equation defines the internal rate of return. IRR represents the discount rate that makes the NPV of all cash flows equal to zero. CF_t are the cash flows at time t. IRR is widely used in capital budgeting decisions. IRR can have multiple solutions for unconventional cash flows.

title: Profitability Index

notes: This equation calculates the profitability index. PI represents the benefit-cost ratio of an investment, NPV is the net present value, and Initial Investment is the upfront capital required. Projects with PI greater than 1 are acceptable.

title: Modified Internal Rate of Return

title: Payback Period

title: Discounted Payback Period

title: Net Present Value
notes: This equation calculates the net present value of an investment. NPV represents the total value created by the investment, CF_t are cash flows at time t, r is the discount rate, and n is the project life. Positive NPV indicates value creation. NPV directly measures value creation in dollar terms.

title: Capital Asset Pricing Model for Projects

notes: This equation defines the indifference price. The indifference price is the amount that makes the investor indifferent between holding the derivative and not holding it. Indifference pricing depends on the investor's utility function U and initial wealth W.

title: Entropy Risk Measure
notes: This equation defines the entropic risk measure. rho(X) represents the risk-adjusted value of the random payoff X

title: Convex Risk Measure
notes: This equation defines a convex risk measure. rho(X) represents the risk measure

title: Ambiguity Aversion
equation_latex: V = inf_{Q in Q} E_{Q}[payoff] + phi(Q)
notes: This equation defines pricing under model uncertainty (ambiguity aversion). V represents the value

title: Good-Deal Bounds
notes: This equation defines the good-deal bounds on the market price of risk theta. The bounds restrict the set of equivalent martingale measures to those that are not too extreme. Good-deal bounds narrow the no-arbitrage price interval by excluding unrealistic pricing measures.

title: Minimal Martingale Measure
notes: This equation defines the minimal martingale measure. The minimal martingale measure is the equivalent martingale measure that is closest to the physical measure in terms of relative entropy. It is used when the market price of risk is not uniquely defined.

title: Föllmer-Schweizer Decomposition
notes: This equation defines the Föllmer-Schweizer decomposition. X_t represents the discounted payoff

title: Mean-Variance Hedging
notes: This equation defines mean-variance hedging. The objective is to minimize the mean-squared hedging error between the payoff and the hedge portfolio. Mean-variance hedging is the optimal quadratic hedging strategy in incomplete markets.

title: Quadratic Hedging
notes: This equation defines quadratic hedging with a traded asset S_t and a residual value V_t. The hedge portfolio minimizes the mean-squared hedging error. Quadratic hedging is widely used when perfect hedging is impossible.

title: Market Price of Model Risk
notes: This equation defines the market price of model risk. lambda_model represents the Sharpe ratio of model risk

title: Model Uncertainty
notes: This equation incorporates model risk into pricing. V represents the risk-adjusted value

title: Deep Hedging
notes: This equation defines deep hedging using neural networks. Hedge_theta represents the hedging strategy parameterized by theta

title: Capitalization Rate
notes: This equation calculates the capitalization rate for real estate. Cap Rate represents the initial yield on a property, NOI is net operating income, and Property Value is the purchase price or market value. Cap rate is used to compare different properties and determine if an investment is attractive based on current income.

title: Net Operating Income
notes: This equation calculates net operating income for real estate. NOI represents the income generated by a property after operating expenses but before debt service and taxes. Effective Gross Income includes rent and other income minus vacancy and collection losses.

title: Effective Gross Income
equation_latex: \text{EGI} = Potential Gross Income - Vacancy and Collection Losses
notes: This equation calculates effective gross income for real estate. EGI represents the actual income collected from tenants after accounting for vacancy and collection losses. Potential Gross Income is the income if all units were occupied at full rent.

title: Gross Rent Multiplier
notes: This equation calculates the gross rent multiplier for real estate. GRM represents how many years of gross rent would be needed to pay for the property. A lower GRM indicates a potentially better investment, though this is a rough metric that doesn't account for expenses.

title: Cash-on-Cash Return
equation_latex: \text{CoC} = Annual Cash Flow / Total Cash Invested
notes: This equation calculates cash-on-cash return for real estate. CoC represents the annual return on the actual cash invested, Annual Cash Flow is after all expenses and debt service, and Total Cash Invested includes down payment and closing costs.

title: Capital Recovery Factor
notes: This equation calculates the capital recovery factor for mortgage amortization. CRF represents the mortgage payment as a percentage of the loan amount, r is the periodic interest rate, and n is the number of periods. This factor is used in real estate finance calculations.

title: Vacancy Rate
equation_latex: Vacancy Rate = Vacant Units / Total Units
notes: This equation calculates the vacancy rate for a property. Vacancy Rate represents the percentage of units that are unoccupied, Vacant Units is the count of empty units, and Total Units is the total number of units. Vacancy impacts effective gross income and NOI.

title: Debt Service Coverage Ratio
notes: This equation calculates the debt service coverage ratio. DSCR represents the ability to cover debt obligations from operating income, NOI is net operating income, and Annual Debt Service is the total principal and interest payments. Lenders typically require DSCR > 1.2.

title: Loan-to-Value Ratio
notes: This equation calculates the loan-to-value ratio. LTV represents the percentage of the property value financed by debt, Loan Amount is the mortgage principal, and Property Value is the purchase price or appraisal. LTV affects interest rates and loan eligibility.

title: Internal Rate of Return (Real Estate)
notes: This equation calculates IRR for real estate investments. IRR represents the annualized return accounting for all cash flows including operating income, capital expenditures, refinancing, and sale. Real estate IRR typically targets 10-15%. IRR can have multiple solutions for unconventional cash flows.

title: Multiple on Invested Capital
notes: This equation calculates the multiple on invested capital. MOIC represents the total return as a multiple of the initial investment, Total Distributions include all cash flows to investors, and Total Equity Invested is the total capital called. MOIC is commonly reported by private equity firms.

title: Public Market Equivalent
notes: This equation calculates the public market equivalent. LPME represents the multiple achieved relative to a public market benchmark, CF_t are distributions, r_benchmark is the benchmark return, and Initial Investment is the capital deployed. This compares PE performance to public markets.

title: Limited Partner Commitment
notes: This equation calculates the commitment from limited partners. LP Commitment represents the capital pledged by LPs to the fund, Fund Size is the total target capital, and LP Percentage is the LP's ownership percentage. LPs commit capital that is drawn down over time.

title: General Partner Carried Interest
equation_latex: \text{GP} Carried Interest = 20% \times (Total Distributions - Return of Capital)
notes: This equation calculates the general partner carried interest. GP Carried Interest represents the profit share for the GP, which is typically 20% of profits after LPs receive their return of capital. This aligns GP and LP incentives.

title: Catch-Up Provision
notes: This equation describes the catch-up provision in PE compensation. After the catch-up, the GP receives a higher percentage (typically 40-50%) until the preferred return is met. This accelerates GP compensation after LPs recover their investment.

title: Preferred Return
equation_latex: \text{LP} Preferred Return = Initial Investment \times Preferred Rate \times Time
notes: This equation calculates the preferred return for LPs. LP Preferred Return represents the return that must be paid to LPs before the GP participates in profits, typically 8% annually. This is a key term in PE partnership agreements.

title: Management Fee
equation_latex: Management Fee = Fund Size \times Fee Rate
notes: This equation calculates the annual management fee. Management Fee represents the fee paid to the GP for managing the fund, typically 1.5-2% of committed capital in early years and 0.5-1% of invested capital in later years.

title: Sharpe Ratio for Hedge Funds
equation_latex: Sharpe = (Strategy Return - Risk-Free Rate) / Strategy Volatility
notes: This equation calculates the Sharpe ratio for hedge fund strategies. Sharpe represents risk-adjusted return, Strategy Return is the absolute return, Risk-Free Rate is the benchmark, and Strategy Volatility is the standard deviation of returns. Hedge fund Sharpe ratios often look attractive due to low volatility.

title: Sortino Ratio
notes: This equation calculates the Sortino ratio, a downside risk measure. Sortino represents return per unit of downside risk, R_p is portfolio return, R_f is the risk-free rate, and sigma_down is the standard deviation of negative returns. This is preferred for asymmetric return distributions.

title: Calmar Ratio
notes: This equation calculates the Calmar ratio for hedge funds. Calmar represents return per unit of maximum drawdown, Annual Return is the average annual return, and Maximum Drawdown is the largest peak-to-trough decline. This is particularly relevant for trend-following strategies.

title: Information Ratio
notes: This equation calculates the information ratio for hedge funds. IR represents active return per unit of tracking error, which measures how consistently a strategy outperforms its benchmark. Higher IR indicates better skill.

title: Maximum Drawdown
notes: Alternative Investments - Hedge Funds,This equation calculates the maximum drawdown for hedge funds. MDD represents the largest peak-to-trough decline, Peak_t is the maximum value before the decline, and Trough_t is the lowest value after. Drawdown risk is crucial for evaluating hedge fund strategies.

title: Sterling Ratio
notes: This equation calculates the Sterling ratio. Sterling represents return per unit of average drawdown, R_p is portfolio return, R_f is risk-free rate, and Average Drawdown is the mean of all drawdowns. This complements maximum drawdown with average severity.

title: Burke Ratio
notes: This equation calculates the Burke ratio. Burke represents return per unit of root-mean-square drawdown, which weights larger drawdowns more heavily. This is a more conservative measure of drawdown risk.

title: CTA Strategy Return
notes: Alternative Investments - Hedge Funds,This equation calculates the return of a multi-strategy CTA. R_CTA represents the overall CTA return, w_i are the strategy weights, and R_strategy,i are the returns of individual strategies. CTA strategies often include trend-following across multiple asset classes.

title: Managed Futures Exposure
equation_latex: Exposure = sum_{i=1}^{n} w_{i} \times (1 + beta_{i}) \times V_{i} / Total Vol
notes: This equation calculates the effective exposure of a managed futures portfolio. Exposure represents the systematic market exposure, w_i are positions, beta_i are market betas, V_i are notional values, and Total Vol is the portfolio volatility. Managed futures can have high effective leverage.

title: Equity Market Neutral Return
equation_latex: R_{EMN} = alpha + sum beta_{j} \times F_{j} + epsilon
notes: This equation models the return of an equity market neutral strategy. R_EMN represents the strategy return, alpha is the stock selection skill, beta_j are factor exposures, F_j are factor returns, and epsilon is the idiosyncratic return. Market neutral means zero net market beta.

title: Convertible Bond Delta
notes: This equation approximates the delta of a convertible bond. Delta_CB represents the sensitivity to the underlying stock, R is the recovery rate, and Delta_option is the option delta. Convertible bonds have option-like payoffs.

title: Contingent Convertible (CoCo) Trigger
notes: Discretionary,Alternative Investments - Structured Products,This equation defines the trigger for contingent convertible bonds. Trigger represents when the CoCo converts to equity or takes a loss, CET1 Ratio is the core equity tier 1 capital ratio, Capital Ratio is total capital ratio, and Discretionary allows issuer intervention.

title: Tranche Attachment Point
equation_latex: Attachment = Loss Level where Tranche begins to absorb losses
notes: This equation defines the attachment point of a structured product tranche. Attachment represents the percentage loss level at which the tranche starts absorbing losses. Lower attachment points mean higher risk and higher yield.

title: Tranche Detachment Point
notes: This equation defines the detachment point of a structured product tranche. Detachment represents the percentage loss level at which the tranche is completely wiped out. The tranche absorbs losses between attachment and detachment.

title: Expected Tranche Loss
notes: This equation calculates the expected loss on a structured product tranche. ETL represents the average loss the tranche will incur, PDF(Loss) is the probability density of portfolio losses, and integration is from attachment to detachment. This is key for pricing and risk management.

title: Subordination Level
notes: This equation calculates the subordination level of a tranche. Subordination represents how much of the portfolio is junior to the tranche, Attachment Point is the loss level where the tranche starts absorbing losses, and Total Portfolio is the full notional. Higher subordination means lower risk.

title: Waterfall Distribution
notes: Alternative Investments - Structured Products,This equation describes the waterfall distribution in structured products. Senior tranche payments are the remaining cash flow after satisfying junior tranche requirements. Junior tranches absorb losses first, providing credit enhancement to seniors.

title: Collateral Coverage
equation_latex: Coverage = Collateral Value / Senior Tranche Notional
notes: This equation calculates the collateral coverage for a structured product. Coverage represents how well the collateral backs the senior tranche, Collateral Value is the mark-to-market value of assets, and Senior Tranche Notional is the senior tranche size. Coverage below 100% increases senior risk.

title: Covered Interest Parity
notes: This equation defines covered interest parity. F represents the forward exchange rate, S is the spot exchange rate, r_domestic is the domestic interest rate, and r_foreign is the foreign interest rate. CIP must hold to prevent arbitrage opportunities in the foreign exchange market.

title: Uncovered Interest Parity
notes: This equation defines uncovered interest parity. E[F] represents the expected future spot rate, S is the current spot rate, r_domestic is the domestic interest rate, and r_foreign is the foreign interest rate. UIP is a theoretical condition that often does not hold in practice.

title: Forward Premium
notes: This equation calculates the forward premium or discount. Forward Premium represents the percentage difference between forward and spot rates. Positive values indicate the domestic currency is trading at a forward premium (stronger forward than spot).

title: Forward Discount
notes: This equation calculates the forward discount. Forward Discount represents the percentage by which the forward rate is below the spot rate. A forward discount indicates the domestic currency is expected to weaken.

title: Continuous Covered Parity
notes: This equation defines covered interest parity with continuous compounding. F represents the forward rate, S is the spot rate, r_domestic and r_foreign are continuously compounded interest rates, and T is time to maturity. This form is widely used in derivatives pricing.

title: Forward Rate Agreement Value
main_category: Currency and FX - Interest Rate Parity
notes: This equation calculates the value of a Forward Rate Agreement. V_FRA represents the mark-to-market value, N is the notional, L is the realized LIBOR rate, K is the agreed FRA rate, delta is the day count fraction, and DF is the discount factor.

title: Forward Rate Agreement Rate
equation_latex: FRA Rate = ((1 + r_{long} \times T_{long}) / (1 + r_{short} \times T_{short}) - 1) \times (360 / delta)
main_category: Currency and FX - Interest Rate Parity
notes: This equation calculates the FRA rate. FRA Rate represents the rate agreed in the FRA contract, r_long is the rate for the longer period, r_short is the rate for the shorter period, T_long and T_short are the year fractions, and delta is the day count in days.

title: Purchasing Power Parity (Absolute)
main_category: Currency and FX - Purchasing Power Parity
notes: This equation defines absolute purchasing power parity. S represents the exchange rate that equalizes the purchasing power of two currencies, P_domestic is the domestic price level, and P_foreign is the foreign price level. This is the law of one price applied to price levels.

title: Purchasing Power Parity (Relative)
main_category: Currency and FX - Purchasing Power Parity
notes: This equation defines relative purchasing power parity. S_1/S_0 represents the change in the exchange rate, inflation_domestic is the domestic inflation rate, and inflation_foreign is the foreign inflation rate. This predicts how exchange rates adjust for inflation differentials.

title: Real Exchange Rate
main_category: Currency and FX - Purchasing Power Parity
notes: This equation calculates the real exchange rate. RER represents the relative price of goods across countries, S is the nominal exchange rate, P_foreign is the foreign price level, and P_domestic is the domestic price level. RER deviations from 1 indicate real exchange rate misalignment.

title: Big Mac Index
equation_latex: Big Mac PPP = Local Price / US Price
main_category: Currency and FX - Purchasing Power Parity
notes: This equation defines the Big Mac index methodology. Big Mac PPP represents the implied exchange rate based on Big Mac prices, Local Price is the Big Mac price in local currency, and US Price is the Big Mac price in the US. This provides a simple PPP benchmark.

title: FX Forward Valuation
notes: This equation calculates the value of an FX forward. V_forward represents the mark-to-market value, F_market is the market forward rate, F_theoretical is the contract forward rate, N is the notional, and DF is the discount factor.

title: Cross Rate
notes: This equation calculates a cross exchange rate. S_cross represents the exchange rate between currencies A and B, S_A/USD is the rate between A and USD, and S_B/USD is the rate between B and USD. Cross rates are derived from rates against a common currency.

title: Triangular Arbitrage
notes: This equation defines the no-arbitrage condition for triangular arbitrage. S_A/B represents the direct rate, S_A/USD and S_USD/B are cross rates through USD. Any arbitrage opportunities that deviation creates should be quickly eliminated.

title: Currency Option Delta (Call)
notes: This equation calculates the delta of a currency call option. Delta_C represents the sensitivity to the spot rate, q is the foreign risk-free rate, T is time to expiration, and N(d_1) is the cumulative normal distribution. Foreign currency options use the Garman-Kohlhagen model.

title: Currency Option Delta (Put)
notes: This equation calculates the delta of a currency put option. Delta_P represents the sensitivity to the spot rate, q is the foreign risk-free rate, T is time to expiration, and N(-d_1) is the cumulative normal. Put delta is negative, as put prices fall when the currency appreciates.

title: Garman-Kohlhagen Call Price
equation_latex: C = e^{-r_{d} T} \times (F \times N \times (d_{1}) - K \times N \times (d_{2}))
notes: This equation prices a European currency call option using the Garman-Kohlhagen model. C represents the call price, r_d is the domestic rate, F is the forward rate, K is the strike, and N(d) are cumulative normal distributions. This extends Black-Scholes for two currencies.

title: Garman-Kohlhagen d_1
notes: This equation defines d_1 for the Garman-Kohlhagen model. d_1 combines the moneyness (ln(F/K)), volatility sigma, and time to expiration T. This parameter is used in both the call and put pricing formulas.

title: Currency Put-Call Parity
equation_latex: C + K \times e^{-r_{d} T} = P + F \times e^{-q T}
notes: This equation defines put-call parity for currency options. C and P are call and put prices, K is the strike, r_d is the domestic rate, q is the foreign rate, and F is the forward rate. This no-arbitrage relationship links call and put prices.

title: Carry Trade Return
notes: This equation calculates the expected return from a carry trade. R_carry represents the expected return from borrowing in low-yield currencies and investing in high-yield currencies, r_foreign and r_domestic are interest rates, and the last term is expected depreciation.

title: Carry Trade Sharpe Ratio
equation_latex: Sharpe = (r_{foreign} - r_{domestic} - sigma_{S} \times sigma_{R} \times rho) / sigma_{carry}
notes: This equation calculates the Sharpe ratio for carry trades. Sharpe represents risk-adjusted carry return, r_foreign - r_domestic is the interest rate differential, sigma_S is spot volatility, sigma_R is the risk premium, rho is correlation, and sigma_carry is carry volatility.

title: FX Swap Points
equation_latex: Swap Points = F - S = S \times (r_{d} - r_{f}) \times T
notes: This equation calculates the swap points for an FX swap. Swap Points represent the difference between forward and spot rates, which approximately equals the interest rate differential times the spot rate and time to maturity.

title: FX Implied Volatility
notes: This equation relates implied to realized volatility for currency pairs. sigma_implied represents the volatility implied by option prices, sigma_realized is historical volatility, and rho is the correlation between spot returns and volatility. Implied volatility is typically higher for currencies.

title: Currency Basis
main_category: Currency and FX - Cross Currency Swaps
notes: This equation calculates the currency basis in cross-currency swaps. Currency Basis represents the deviation from covered interest parity, F_market is the market forward rate, and F_CIP is the CIP-implied forward. A positive basis indicates funding pressure in the foreign currency.

title: Cross Currency Swap Spread
equation_latex: CCS Spread = R_{domestic} - R_{foreign} - (S_{0} - F_{CIP}) / S_{0}
main_category: Currency and FX - Cross Currency Swaps
notes: This equation calculates the cross-currency swap spread. CCS Spread represents the differential between domestic and foreign rates adjusted for the forward points, R_domestic and R_foreign are rates, S_0 is spot, and F_CIP is the CIP forward.

title: FX Risk Reversal
equation_latex: Risk Reversal = Call Vol - Put Vol
notes: This equation calculates the FX risk reversal. Risk Reversal represents the volatility difference between out-of-the-money calls and puts, which indicates market skew. Positive risk reversal means calls are more expensive (market expects currency appreciation).

title: FX Butterfly
equation_latex: Butterfly = (AtM Vol + 25D Call Vol + 25D Put Vol) / 3 - AtM Vol
notes: This equation calculates the FX butterfly spread. Butterfly represents the curvature of the volatility smile, AtM Vol is at-the-money volatility, and 25D Call/Put are 25-delta option volatilities. This measures the smile curvature.

title: FX Delta Neutral Straddle
notes: This equation describes a delta-neutral straddle using 25-delta options. Straddle represents buying equal amounts of 25-delta calls and puts to create a position that profits from volatility regardless of direction. This is a common volatility trading strategy.

title: NDF Valuation
notes: This equation calculates the value of a Non-Deliverable Forward. V_NDF represents the mark-to-market value, N is the notional in USD, S_market is the current NDF rate, S_strike is the contract rate, and DF_domestic is the domestic discount factor. NDFs are settled in USD.

title: FX Delta Exposure
notes: This equation calculates the delta exposure in FX. Delta Exposure represents the equivalent spot position, Position Size is the option notional, Delta is the option delta, and S_0 is the spot rate. This is used for hedging and risk management.
